data.text: Contents

The purpose is to provide guidance in assessing a patient over the age of  years who may have sustained fractured rib/s. This is the first step to methodically and accurately managing the patients' pain. The guideline has been written to provide management advice for these patients. The guideline helps to recognise the potential severity of the injury from the rib fracture and highlights potential multisystem injuries that may occur concurrently with rib fractures, along with ways to control the pain from the rib fracture/s. Pain control for the patient with rib fracture/s is fundamental to decrease respiratory splinting, to clear pulmonary secretions and maintain good respiratory function in order to prevent potential alveolar collapse.
Analgesic management can be divided into discharged / out-patient patients, and those who are admitted into hospital; in-patient management. The guideline will explain both.

Simple rib fractures are a common injury following blunt chest trauma, and they account for over 50% of thoracic injuries from non-penetrating trauma. 10% of patients admitted following blunt chest trauma have multiple rib fractures. The fractures themselves are rarely life threatening where pain is managed appropriately, but are often used as a marker of more severe visceral injuries inside the abdomen and the chest. The general causes of injury for rib fractures include; for the elderly – a fall from a height or standing, in adults – RTA's are the most common cause, and for younger patients from recreational / athletic activities, as well as non-accidental trauma. Rib fractures may also be pathologic in cause; this is generally as a result of metastatic disease.
Rib fractures may compromise ventilation by a variety of mechanisms:

The pain from the rib fractures will cause respiratory splinting, if not controlled, will result in atelectasis (the collapse of lung tissue leading to the absence of air from part or all of the lungs), and pneumonia

Where the patient has a flail chest (a life-threatening medical condition that occurs when a segment of the rib cage breaks and becomes detached from the rest of the chest wall. It occurs when multiple adjacent ribs are broken in multiple places, so a part of the chest wall moves independently, interfering with normal respiratory movement)
Fragments of fractured ribs can also act as penetrating objects leading to the formation of a haemothorax (blood in the pleural cavity) or a pneumothorax (air in the pleural cavity).

Risk factors associated with complications following rib fractures include; where patient's age ≥ 85 years, their initial systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg, where haemothorax or pneumothorax is present, where there are 3 or more unilateral rib fractures, and / or pulmonary contusion.

Pneumothorax occurs in about 14% to 35% of rib fractures, haemo-pneumothorax in 20% to 25%, pulmonary contusions in 17%, and a flail chest in 5.8%; increasing incidence correlates with an increased number of fractures. Traumatic injuries to the first rib have a 3% risk of concomitant large vessel injury. These risk factors have been used to predict adverse events occurring. Adverse events include; acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), pneumonia, unanticipated intubation, transfers to ITU for hypoxaemia, and / or death. Research has also shown the presence of cardiopulmonary disease significantly increases morbidity and mortality in patients over 65 years. Rib fractures are the most common injury in elderly blunt chest trauma patients, and each additional rib fracture increases the odds of dying by 19% and of developing pneumonia by 27%. These findings will be used to help guide treatment in MSE NHS Trust
Patient rib fractures can also highlight potential damage to underlying structures. The table below highlights this. This will help to form the basis of further investigations if required.

table_items.text: Position of the fractured rib in the thorax helps identify potential injury to specific underlying organs

First rib fractures have often been described as having a high association with serious spinal or vascular injuries. They are the rarest of all rib fractures. They are associated with severe trauma. They may involve spinal fractures, injury to the lung, ascending aorta, subclavian artery, and / or the brachial plexus. They require an MDT approach, CT neck and chest are required. Complications associated with first rib fractures include delayed subclavian vessel thrombosis, aortic aneurysm, tracheobronchial fistula, thoracic outlet syndrome, and Horner's syndrome.
Fracture/s of the lower ribs are usually associated with injury to the abdominal organs rather than to lung parenchyma.
Fracture of the right lower ribs can be associated with liver injuries.
Fracture of the left lower ribs can be associated with splenic injuries.
Fracture of the floating ribs (ribs 11, 12) can often be associated with renal injuries.
Ribs 4-9 are the most commonly seen rib fractures.
Ribs commonly fracture at the point of impact or at the posterior angle; structurally their weakest area.

data.text: Scope
Patients over the age of 16 years, who present with possible rib fracture/s.
Definitions
Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
All qualified nursing and medical staff have individual responsibility to practice within these guidelines.
Ward and Unit managers are responsible for ensuring availability of the guidelines and to facilitate training when required.
IPMS is responsible for ensuring current evidence based review of guidelines and to provide training and education.
The Trust Executive Board has overall responsibility for corporate level governance.
Pain assessment
Patient history check list:
RTA (car driver, motorcyclist); steering wheel deformity and activation of airbag are associated with # ribs. Ask paramedics bringing patient to A&E
Penetrating wound, e.g. Gunshot wound, stab wound
Reported after coughing spells where there is no trauma reported
Athletes; stress fractures of upper / middle ribs, e.g. javelin, discus throwers.
Non-accidental trauma, e.g. assault;
Falls.
Patients clinical findings:
Patients with rib fracture frequently will complain of pain on inspiration and dyspnoea. Pain on patient twisting and bending;
Visible bruising around the rib area is not particularly common;
Tenderness on palpation, crepitus, and chest wall deformity are common findings; consider flail chest;
Signs of ventilatory insufficiency; cyanosis, tachypnea, retractions, and use of accessory muscles for ventilation, e.g. abdominal breathing;

The rate of significant complications associated complications with rib fractures increases with the number and severity (eg displacement) of fractures, patient fragility and compromised respiratory function, either acute or chronic due to underlying disease;
Patient may be anxious / scared.
Diagnosis:
6.3.1 Differential diagnosis:

6.3.2 Diagnosis can be reached by physical examination and clinical presentation. Chest radiological studies are also used to confirm findings, looking for pneumothorax, haemothorax or other signs of intrathoracic injury. Generally x-rays are used; anteroposterior (AP), and lateral chest films. However, findings show that their sensitivity to finding a fracture can be as low as 50%. If there is high suspicion for pathologic or multiple rib fractures not apparent on plain chest radiographs, an ultrasound, CT scan, bone scan or rib films are advised, angiography may also be used (where vascular damage is also suspected).

6.3.3 CT is invaluable for identifying intrathoracic and intraabdominal injuries and demonstrates greater sensitivity and specificity for rib fractures compared to plain radiographs. Ultrasound is an effective tool for evaluating potentially dangerous complications of rib fractures, such as pneumothorax. An MRI or preferably a bone scan would be the instrument of choice to identify rib stress fractures
Pain management aim
The aim is to stabilise the trauma patient and assess for multisystem injuries and treat accordingly.

Early, adequate pain relief is essential to avoid complications. Pain control is fundamental to decrease respiratory splinting, to clear pulmonary secretions and maintain good respiratory function in order to prevent potential alveolar collapse.
Analgesic management can be divided into discharged / out-patient patients, and those who are admitted into hospital; in-patient management.
Discharged / out-patient pain management

Where patients are able to cough and clear secretions they can be discharged with adequate analgesia. ‘Adequate' analgesia is essential. 50% of patients who return to the GP / A & E complain of uncontrolled pain.
Patients to go back to their GP if still complaining of significant pain; most complications will develop in the 1st 2 weeks post injury if they are going to occur.
Suggest the patient use a pillow to brace their chest wall when coughing / having physiotherapy to reduce pain.
Patients should be made aware that pain can last up to 8 weeks, during which time adequate pain relief should be taken.

Strenuous activities should be avoided for the first three to four weeks following the fracture, but after this, physical exercise can be undertaken as pain allows. No attempt should be made by a patient to participate in contact sports for six weeks so as to avoid the possibility of further damage.

Patients are to be advised that if they develop a high temperature, experience abdominal pain, and / or have increased difficulty breathing, and / or cough up thick or discoloured sputum they should contact their doctor or A & E.
An advice sheet taken from the NHS choices website can be given to the patient. See Appendix  http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/rib-injuries/Pages/Introduction.aspx
Admitted / in-patient pain management
Consider admission for those, this may be under the care of medics or surgeons:
Patients unable to cough or clear secretions adequately, or oxygen saturations below 92% on room air, and those with an inability to perform incentive spirometry greater than 15mL/kg;
Patients aged  years and over (even for a single fracture);
Younger adults considered to be frail;
Patients with initial systolic BP < 90 mmHg;
Patients with haemothorax / pneumothorax;
Patients with 3 or more unilateral rib fractures;
Patients with pulmonary contusion;
Patients where intra-abdominal injury is suspected.
Aim is to avoid these complications:
Respiratory failure;
Hypoventilation;
Hypercapnia;
Hypoxia;
Atelectasis;
Pneumonia;
Damage to underlying organs;
Pneumothorax and / Haemothorax (immediate or delayed);
Aortic injury.

Where patients with trauma are on anticoagulants, very careful consideration should be given to whether to continue / discontinue and +/- reverse anticoagulation on an individual risk / benefit assessment. This should be discussed with the relevant medical specialty inpatient teams (e.g. Cardiology) and the Haematology Consultant on duty.
Pain management
Pain assessment / score are to be carried out on movement / deep breathing
Referral to on-call anaesthetist / Trauma Team / IPMS is essential
General analgesia; using WHO Analgesic ladder depending on the patient's level of pain. For isolated injuries (ie single rib fracture) begin with paracetamol and NSAIDS with or without opioids.
Holding a pillow against the fracture site reduces discomfort while deep breathing/coughing.
For more severe injuries, particularly if ventilation is compromised, invasive treatments such as intercostal nerve blocks maybe required.
If a peripheral / central nerve block is used in addition, ensure that opioids go via one single route only
PCA (opioid) may be useful
Consider paravertebral block (local anaesthetic) for unilateral rib fractures.

Intercostal nerve block: Immediately below each rib travels its neurovascular bundle, including the intercostal vein, artery, and nerve. An Intercostal nerve block (local anaesthetic) can be used without affecting respiratory function. Generally not suitable for multiple fractures as multiple levels of intercostal blocks will be required. Risks of this procedure do include intravascular injection and pneumothorax
Epidural analgesia (local anaesthetic and opioid) may be considered also.
Entonox is not to be used where a haemothorax or pneumothorax is suspected (Refer to Multiple rib fracture pain management algorithm)
Ventilatory management
Ventilatory management is essential for the recovery of the patient and to prevent complications occurring due to rib fracture. Without adequate pain control this cannot be optimised.
Supplementary humidified Oxygen should be given to the patient to help loosen secretions and help sputum clearance.

Bronchodilators and nebulised saline may be prescribed and given regularly to aid the expectoration of secretions and should be linked with physiotherapy. Physiotherapy is helpful but will be hindered by the patient's ability to co-operate due to uncontrolled pain. The patient's pain needs to be controlled.
Physiotherapy exercises
The patient if able is taught the active cycle breathing technique.

The Active Cycle of Breathing Techniques (ACBT) is an active breathing technique performed by the patient to help clear their sputum in their lungs. The ACBT is a group of techniques which use breathing exercises to improve the effectiveness of the persons cough, to help loosen and clear secretions and improve ventilation. E
If the patients PaO2 cannot be maintained; CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure) may be helpful.
Sedation and invasive ventilation may be necessary although not desirable.
Infection control

Trust policy for prevention of cross infection to be adhered to for all patient contact procedures. The infection prevention practice within MEHT is for all staff to have strict hand hygiene before and after patient contact. Any equipment must be cleaned between patients unless it is a single use item which will be disposed of appropriately as per the Waste Management Policy.
Use Aseptic Non-Touch Technique (ANTT) when administering injections.
Staffing and training
Medical, nursing, and therapy staff are expected to have an understanding for the need of assessing and treating fractured ribs proactively, effectively, and safely.

Training and education is provided by the IPMS, both formally and informally for all clinical staff. The IPMS is available for advice and consultation via the pager system, and through the Lorenzo referral system.
In addition, the clinical guideline will be disseminated to the ward through Pain Link nurses within their ward setting.
The new guideline will be introduced to anaesthetic staff through anaesthetic meetings, and to A & E staff.
Pharmacy are involved and made aware of the new guideline.
Corporate services will ensure that the guideline is uploaded to the intranet and notified to staff via the intranet.
Non-compliance with this guideline
Failure to provide regular assessment and effective pain management is a breach of patient rights, and has clinical and non-clinical repercussions:
Patient satisfaction and well-being is compromised;
Accountability and professional responsibility is breached;
Clinical risk is increased, due to multi-systemic influence of pain;
Delayed discharge from hospital decreases Trust efficiency and increases risk of hospital-inquired infection.
A Datix should be completed for non-compliance with this guideline.
Audit and monitoring
Incidence of clinical risk or patient complaints resulting from non- compliance of this guideline is recorded via the central risk events database
The IPMS manager and lead consultant will liaise at corporate level to put strategies in place to address issues.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Pain Service Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Pain Service Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 2)
References
Middleton,C. and Edwards, M. (2003) Management and treatment of patients with fractured ribs Nursing times Vol: 99, Issue: 05, Page
http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/rib-injuries/Pages/Introduction.aspx
http://bestpractice.bmj.com/best-practice/monograph/1009/treatment/step-by- step.html
http://www.uptodate.com/contents/inpatient-management-of-traumatic-rib-fractures  http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/825981-overview

http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/rib-injuries/Pages/Introduction.aspx
